name: Research Department
P1_Title: Prof. Dr. Magdy Ahmed Abd El-Moula Department Head's Speech
P1: Since its establishment, the Maize Research Department has spared no effort in its continuous and diligent work, striving to achieve self-sufficiency in maize, which is the main crop used in the production of feed for livestock, poultry, and fish.
From its inception until now, the Maize Research Department has developed 132 varieties and hybrids of white and yellow maize, sweet corn, and popcorn.

Maize is one of the most important cereal crops worldwide, ranking third after wheat and rice. It is also the number one grain crop in terms of global trade. In 2024, global maize production reached 1,271 million tons, with a market value of 370 billion USD.

Beyond being a staple food source in developing countries, maize plays a vital role in many industries: animal feed for poultry, cattle, and fish; starch and oil production; biofuel production; and certain pharmaceutical industries.

The department continues to develop high-yielding maize hybrids that are resilient to climate change and suitable for multiple uses. This aims to increase crop productivity, narrow the gap between production and consumption, and develop specialty hybrids such as sweet corn and popcorn, ultimately increasing farmers’ income.
P2: The Maize Research Department is one of the largest and most important departments of the Field Crops Research Institute at the Agricultural Research Center.

Department_Achieviements.text: The department has developed numerous high-yielding hybrids, as follows:

children.text: TWC 352, TWC 353, TWC 360, TWC 368, TWC 369, TWC 370, TWC 377

Department_Achieviements.text: Development of improved cultivation practices, especially in the field of water-use efficiency, through:

children.text: Promoting alternate irrigation methods that save 600–800 m³ of water per feddan.
Developing early-maturing hybrids that can be harvested at 95–100 days.
Numerous applied studies have been conducted in breeding and agronomic practices, yielding practical solutions to many challenges through thorough evaluation across different environments.
Demonstration fields are established across most governorates to promote new hybrids, highlight their characteristics, and recommend optimal farming practices for maximum productivity.
Organizing training workshops, field days, harvest days, and publishing guides to communicate research findings to farmers and address challenges faced during the growing season.

Department_Achieviements.text: International and regional cooperation: implementing various protocols for training and knowledge exchange with:

children.text: Exporting maize hybrid seeds to countries such as Algeria and Sudan
The department contributed to the national maize strategy, helping define expected cultivation areas, seed requirements, and addressing challenges during the season.

subItems.text: Developing hybrids with key traits such as heat tolerance, low nitrogen fertilizer requirements, and drought tolerance.
Breeding protein- and amino acid-rich hybrids as well as high-oil content hybrids.

Department_Vision.title: Sustainability
Department_Vision.content: Ensuring continuity in the department’s mission while developing programs to face climate change challenges caused by rising temperatures.

subItems.text: Producing hybrids that can withstand high temperatures and drought.
Producing early-maturing hybrids to reduce irrigation water use.

Department_Vision.title: Conservation
Department_Vision.content: Maintaining and expanding the cultivated maize area.

subItems.text: Producing multipurpose hybrids for grain and silage to increase farmers’ returns.
Developing mechanized planting and harvesting methods to reduce costs.
Expanding maize use in various industries such as starch, oil, and pharmaceuticals to increase revenue and cultivated area.
Enhancing contract farming systems to encourage maize cultivation expansion.
Ongoing monitoring of hybrid release systems with private sector companies to protect and expand the department’s rights.
Protecting the environment by developing systems to utilize maize residues, increasing farmers’ profits.
Advancing applied research to provide innovative solutions to production challenges.

Department_Mission_Outer.title: Developing a strategic plan to advance maize production.
Preserving both local and imported genetic resources.
Breeding new hybrids of white, yellow, sweet corn, and popcorn varieties.
Developing hybrids tolerant to environmental stresses and suitable for cultivation in new regions such as East Oweinat, Toshka, the Future of Egypt Project, Wadi Al-Sa’ida, and Aswan.
Defining and applying optimal agricultural practices to maximize maize productivity.
Multiplying breeder seeds from lines and single-cross hybrids used in commercial hybrid production.
Producing certified seeds of white, yellow, and red grain hybrids (single and three-way crosses).
Establishing demonstration and educational fields to introduce farmers to new hybrids and suitable agricultural practices.
